    ℒrT2​(ftaskT2)=‖ftaskT2​(𝐱^S)−𝐲S‖1subscriptsuperscriptℒT2𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝑓T2tasksubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝑓T2tasksubscript^𝐱𝑆subscript𝐲𝑆1\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{T2}}_{r}(f^{\textsc{T2}}_{\mathrm{task}})=\left\|f^{\textsc{T2}}_{\mathrm{task}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S})-\mathbf{y}_{S}\right\|_{1} is the task loss for depth estimation on synthetic images, namely the L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-norm of the difference between the predicted depth map for a translated synthetic image 𝐱^Ssubscript^𝐱𝑆\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S} and the original ground truth synthetic depth map 𝐲Ssubscript𝐲𝑆\mathbf{y}_{S}; this loss ensures that the translation does not change the depth map;

  • •

    ℒsT2​(ftaskT2)=|∂xftaskT2​(𝐱T)|−|∂x𝐱T|+|∂yftaskT2​(𝐱T)|−|∂y𝐱T|subscriptsuperscriptℒT2𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑓T2tasksuperscriptsubscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑓T2tasksubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑥subscript𝐱𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑦subscriptsuperscript𝑓T2tasksubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑦subscript𝐱𝑇\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{T2}}_{s}(f^{\textsc{T2}}_{\mathrm{task}})=\left|\partial_{x}f^{\textsc{T2}}_{\mathrm{task}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right|^{-|\partial_{x}\mathbf{x}_{T}|}+\left|\partial_{y}f^{\textsc{T2}}_{\mathrm{task}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right|^{-|\partial_{y}\mathbf{x}_{T}|}, where ∂xsubscript𝑥\partial_{x} and ∂ysubscript𝑦\partial_{y} are image gradients, is the task loss for depth estimation on real images; since ground truth depth maps are not available now, this regularizer is a locally smooth loss intended to optimize object boundaries, a common tool in depth estimation models [204].

Zheng et al. show that T2superscriptT2\text{T}^{2}Net can produce realistic images from synthetic ones, conclude that end-to-end training is preferable over separated training (of the translation network and depth estimation network), and note that T2superscriptT2\text{T}^{2}Net can achieve good results for depth estimation with no access to real paired data, even outperforming some (but not all) supervised approaches.

We note a few more interesting applications of refiner-based architectures. Wang et al. [633] use a classical refiner modeled after [545] for human motion synthesis and control. Their model first generates a motion sequence from a recurrent neural network and then refines it with a GAN; since the goal is to model and refine sequences, both generator and discriminator in the refiner also have RNN-based architectures. Dilipkumar [148] applied SimGAN to improve handwriting recognition. They generated synthetic handwriting images and applied SimGAN to refine them, with significantly improved recognition of real handwriting after training on a hybrid dataset.

A recent example that applies GAN-based refinement in a classical computer vision setting is provided by Wang et al. [623]. They consider the problem of recognizing objects inside an automatic vending machines; this is a basic functionality needed for monotoring the state of supplies and is usually done based on object detection. Wang et al. begin by scanning the objects, adding random deformations to the resulting 3D models (see Section 5.2), setting up scenes and rendering with settings matching the fisheye cameras used in smart vending machines. Then they refine rendered images with virtual-to-real style transfer done by a CycleGAN-based architecture. The novelty here is that Wang et al. separate foreground and background losses, arguing that style transfer needed for foreground objects is very different from (much stronger than) the style transfer for backgrounds. Thus, they use the overall loss function

ℒOD=superscriptℒODabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}= ℒGANOD​(GOD,DTOD,𝒳S,𝒳T)+ℒGANOD​(FOD,DSOD,𝒳T,𝒳S)+subscriptsuperscriptℒODGANsuperscript𝐺ODsubscriptsuperscript𝐷OD𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇limit-fromsubscriptsuperscriptℒODGANsuperscript𝐹ODsubscriptsuperscript𝐷OD𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{OD}},D^{\textsc{OD}}_{T},\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{T})+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(F^{\textsc{OD}},D^{\textsc{OD}}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{T},\mathcal{X}_{S})+
+\displaystyle+ λ1​ℒcycOD​(GOD,FOD)+λ2​ℒbgOD+λ3​ℒfgOD,where:subscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒODcycsuperscript𝐺ODsuperscript𝐹ODsubscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptℒODbgsubscript𝜆3subscriptsuperscriptℒODfgwhere:\displaystyle\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}(G^{\textsc{OD}},F^{\textsc{OD}})+\lambda_{2}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{bg}}+\lambda_{3}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{fg}},\quad\text{where:}
  • •

    ℒGANOD​(G,D,X,Y)subscriptsuperscriptℒODGAN𝐺𝐷𝑋𝑌\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G,D,X,Y) is the standard adversarial loss for generator G𝐺G mapping from domain X𝑋X to domain Y𝑌Y and discriminator D𝐷D distinguishing real images from fake ones in the domain Y𝑌Y;

  • •

    ℒcycOD​(G,F)subscriptsuperscriptℒODcyc𝐺𝐹\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}(G,F) is the cycle consistency loss as used in CycleGAN [714] and detailed above;

  • •

    ℒbgODsubscriptsuperscriptℒODbg\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{bg}} is the background loss, which is the cycle consistency loss computed only for the background part of the images as defined by the mask 𝐦bgsubscript𝐦bg\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{bg}}:

    ℒbgOD=subscriptsuperscriptℒODbgabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{bg}}= 𝔼𝐱T∼preal​[‖(GOD​(FOD​(𝐱T))−𝐱T)⊙𝐦bg​(𝐱T)‖2]subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝realdelimited-[]subscriptnormdirect-productsuperscript𝐺ODsuperscript𝐹ODsubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝐦bgsubscript𝐱𝑇2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}}\left[\left\|\left(G^{\textsc{OD}}(F^{\textsc{OD}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}))-\mathbf{x}_{T}\right)\odot\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{bg}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right\|_{2}\right]
    +\displaystyle+ 𝔼𝐱S∼psyn​[‖(FOD​(GOD​(𝐱S))−𝐱S)⊙𝐦bg​(𝐱S)‖2];subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syndelimited-[]subscriptnormdirect-productsuperscript𝐹ODsuperscript𝐺ODsubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝐦bgsubscript𝐱𝑆2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}}}\left[\left\|\left(F^{\textsc{OD}}(G^{\textsc{OD}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))-\mathbf{x}_{S}\right)\odot\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{bg}}(\mathbf{x}_{S})\right\|_{2}\right];
  • •

    ℒfgODsubscriptsuperscriptℒODfg\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{fg}} is the foreground loss, similar to ℒbgODsubscriptsuperscriptℒODbg\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{bg}} but computed only for the hue channel in the HSV color space (the authors argue that color and profile are the most critical for recognition and thus need to be preserved the most), as denoted by ⋅Hsuperscript⋅𝐻\cdot^{H} below:

    ℒfgOD=subscriptsuperscriptℒODfgabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{OD}}_{\mathrm{fg}}= 𝔼𝐱T∼preal​[‖(GOD​(FOD​(𝐱T))H−𝐱TH)⊙𝐦fg​(𝐱T)‖2]subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝realdelimited-[]subscriptnormdirect-productsuperscript𝐺ODsuperscriptsuperscript𝐹ODsubscript𝐱𝑇𝐻superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑇𝐻subscript𝐦fgsubscript𝐱𝑇2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}}\left[\left\|\left(G^{\textsc{OD}}(F^{\textsc{OD}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}))^{H}-\mathbf{x}_{T}^{H}\right)\odot\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{fg}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right\|_{2}\right]
    +\displaystyle+ 𝔼𝐱S∼psyn​[‖(FOD​(GOD​(𝐱S))H−𝐱SH)⊙𝐦fg​(𝐱S)‖2].subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syndelimited-[]subscriptnormdirect-productsuperscript𝐹ODsuperscriptsuperscript𝐺ODsubscript𝐱𝑆𝐻superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑆𝐻subscript𝐦fgsubscript𝐱𝑆2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}}}\left[\left\|\left(F^{\textsc{OD}}(G^{\textsc{OD}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))^{H}-\mathbf{x}_{S}^{H}\right)\odot\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{fg}}(\mathbf{x}_{S})\right\|_{2}\right].

Segmentation into foreground and background is done automatically in synthetic data and is made easy in [623] for real data since the camera position is fixed, and the authors can collect a dataset of real background templates from the vending machines they used in the experiments and then simply subtract the backgrounds to get the foreground part. As a result, Wang et al. report significantly improved results when using hybrid datasets of real and synthetic data for all three tested object detection architectures: PVANET [320], SSD [372], and YOLOv3 [482]. Even more importantly, they report a comparison between basic and refined synthetic data with clear gains achieved by refinement across all architectures.

Wang et al. [625] discuss synthetic-to-real domain adaptation in the context of crowd counting, a domain where synthetic data has been successfully used for a long time. They collect synthetic data with the Grand Theft Auto V engine, producing the so-called GTA5 Crowd Counting (GCC) dataset (see also Section 2.3). They also use a CycleGAN-based refiner from the domain of synthetic images 𝒳Ssubscript𝒳𝑆\mathcal{X}_{S} to the domain of real images 𝒳Tsubscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}_{T} but remark that CycleGAN can easily lose local patterns and textures which is exactly what is important for crowd counting. Therefore, they modify the CycleGAN loss function with the Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) [713] that computes the similarity between images in terms of local patterns. Their final loss function is

ℒSSIM=superscriptℒSSIMabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}= ℒGANSSIM​(GSSIM,DTSSIM,𝒳S,𝒳T)+ℒGANSSIM​(FSSIM,DSSSIM,𝒳T,𝒳S)subscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMGANsuperscript𝐺SSIMsubscriptsuperscript𝐷SSIM𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMGANsuperscript𝐹SSIMsubscriptsuperscript𝐷SSIM𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{SSIM}},D^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{T},\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{T})+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(F^{\textsc{SSIM}},D^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{T},\mathcal{X}_{S})
+λ​ℒcycSSIM​(GSSIM,FSSIM,𝒳S,𝒳R)+μ​ℒSESSIM​(GSSIM,FSSIM,𝒳S,𝒳R),𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMcycsuperscript𝐺SSIMsuperscript𝐹SSIMsubscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑅𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMSEsuperscript𝐺SSIMsuperscript𝐹SSIMsubscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑅\displaystyle+\lambda\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}(G^{\textsc{SSIM}},F^{\textsc{SSIM}},\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{R})+\mu\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{SE}}(G^{\textsc{SSIM}},F^{\textsc{SSIM}},\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{R}),

where GSSIM:𝒳S→𝒳T:superscript𝐺SSIM→subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇G^{\textsc{SSIM}}:\mathcal{X}_{S}\to\mathcal{X}_{T} is the generator from synthetic to real domains, FSSIM:𝒳T→𝒳S:superscript𝐹SSIM→subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆F^{\textsc{SSIM}}:\mathcal{X}_{T}\to\mathcal{X}_{S} works in the opposite direction, DTSSIMsubscriptsuperscript𝐷SSIM𝑇D^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{T} and DSSSIMsubscriptsuperscript𝐷SSIM𝑆D^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{S} are the corresponding discriminators, ℒGANSSIMsubscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMGAN\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{GAN}} is a standard GAN loss function, and ℒcycSSIMsubscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMcyc\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{cyc}} is the cycle consistency loss as defined above, while ℒSESSIMsubscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMSE\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{SE}} is a special loss function designed to improve SSIM:

ℒSESSIM​(GSSIM,FSSIM,𝒳S,𝒳R)=subscriptsuperscriptℒSSIMSEsuperscript𝐺SSIMsuperscript𝐹SSIMsubscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑅absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SSIM}}_{\mathrm{SE}}(G^{\textsc{SSIM}},F^{\textsc{SSIM}},\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{R})= 𝔼𝐱S∼psyn[1−SSIM(𝐱S,FSSIM(GSSIM(𝐱S))]\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}}}\left[1-\mathrm{SSIM}(\mathbf{x}_{S},F^{\textsc{SSIM}}(G^{\textsc{SSIM}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))\right]
+𝔼𝐱T∼pdata[1−SSIM(𝐱T,GSSIM(FSSIM(𝐱T))].\displaystyle+{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{data}}}\left[1-\mathrm{SSIM}(\mathbf{x}_{T},G^{\textsc{SSIM}}(F^{\textsc{SSIM}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}))\right].

Bak et al. [32] (see Section 2.3) use domain translation with synthetic people as a method for person re-identification. The domains in this model are represented by illumination conditions for the images; the model has access to M𝑀M real source domains and N𝑁N synthetic domains, with N≫Mmuch-greater-than𝑁𝑀N\gg M, and the objective is to perform re-identification in an unknown target domain. To achieve this, Bak et al. first learned a generic feature representation from all domains, but the resulting model, even trained on a hybrid dataset, did not generalize well. Therefore, Bak et al. proceeded to domain adaptation done as follows: first choose the nearest synthetic with a separately trained domain identification network fine-tuned for illumination classification, then use the CycleGAN architecture (as shown above) to do domain translation from this synthetic domain to the target domain, and then use the to fine-tune the re-identification network. Bak et al. report improved results from the entire pipeline as compared to any individual parts in the ablation study.

In robotics, domain adaptation of synthetic imagery is not yet common, but some applications have appeared there as well. For example, Pecka et al. [442] train a CycleGAN-based domain adaptation model to learn a transformation from the data observed in a non-differentiable physics simulator and the data from a real robotic platform, showing improved sim-to-real policy transfer results.

6.1.3 Making synthetic data from real with GANs

A related idea is to generate synthetic data from real data by learning to transform real data with conditional GANs. This could either simply serve as “smart augmentation” to extend the dataset or, more interestingly, could “fill in the holes” in the data distribution, obtaining synthetic data for situations that are lacking in the original dataset.

Zhao et al. [708, 707] concentrated on applying this idea to face recognition in the wild, with different poses rather than by a frontal image. They continued the work of Tran et al. [593] (we do not review it in detail) and Huang et al. [264], who presented a TP-GAN (two-pathway GAN) architecture for frontal view synthesis: given a picture of a face, generate a frontal view picture. TP-GAN’s generator GθTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta} has two pathways: a global network GθgTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TPsuperscript𝜃𝑔G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta^{g}} that rotates the entire face and four local patch networks GθilTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TPsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑙𝑖G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta^{l}_{i}}, i=1,…,4𝑖1…4i=1,\ldots,4, that process local textures around four facial landmarks (eyes, nose, and mouth). Both GθgTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TPsuperscript𝜃𝑔G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta^{g}} and GθilTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TPsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑙𝑖G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta^{l}_{i}} have encoder-decoder architectures with skip connections for multi-scale feature fusion. The discriminator DϕTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐷TPitalic-ϕD^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\phi} learns to distinguish real frontal face images 𝐱front∼𝒟frontsimilar-tosubscript𝐱frontsubscript𝒟front\mathbf{x}_{\mathrm{front}}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{front}} from synthesized images GθTP​(𝐱)subscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃𝐱G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}), 𝐱∼pdatasimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑝data\mathbf{x}\sim p_{\mathrm{data}}:

minθ⁡maxϕ⁡[𝔼𝐱front∼𝒟front​[log⁡DϕTP​(𝐱front)]+𝔼𝐱∼pdata​[log⁡(1−DϕTP​(GθTP​(𝐱)))]].subscript𝜃subscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱frontsubscript𝒟frontdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐷TPitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱frontsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱subscript𝑝datadelimited-[]1subscriptsuperscript𝐷TPitalic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃𝐱\min_{\theta}\max_{\phi}\left[{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{\mathrm{front}}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{front}}}\left[\log D^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\phi}(\mathbf{x}_{\mathrm{front}})\right]+{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p_{\mathrm{data}}}\left[\log\left(1-D^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\phi}(G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}))\right)\right]\right].

The synthesis loss function in TP-GAN is a sum of four loss functions:

  • •

    pixel-wise L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-loss between the ground truth frontal image and rotated image:

    ℒpixelTP​(𝐱,𝐱gt)=1W×H​∑i=1W∑j=1H|GθTP​(𝐱)i,j−𝐱i,jgt|,subscriptsuperscriptℒTPpixel𝐱superscript𝐱gt1𝑊𝐻superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃subscript𝐱𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐱gt𝑖𝑗\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\mathrm{pixel}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{gt}})=\frac{1}{W\times H}\sum_{i=1}^{W}\sum_{j=1}^{H}\left|G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})_{i,j}-\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{gt}}_{i,j}\right|,

    where 𝐱gtsuperscript𝐱gt\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{gt}} is the ground truth frontal image corresponding to 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, and W𝑊W and H𝐻H are an image’s width and height; this loss is measured at several different places of the network: output of GθgTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TPsuperscript𝜃𝑔G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta^{g}}, outputs of GθilTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TPsubscriptsuperscript𝜃𝑙𝑖G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta^{l}_{i}}, and the final output of GθTPsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta};

  • •

    symmetry loss

    ℒsymTP=1W/2×H​∑i=1W/2∑j=1H|GθTP​(𝐱)i,j−GθTP​(𝐱)W−(i−1),j|,subscriptsuperscriptℒTPsym1𝑊2𝐻superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑊2superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃subscript𝐱𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃subscript𝐱𝑊𝑖1𝑗\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\mathrm{sym}}=\frac{1}{W/2\times H}\sum_{i=1}^{W/2}\sum_{j=1}^{H}\left|G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})_{i,j}-G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x})_{W-(i-1),j}\right|,

    intended to preserve the symmetry of human faces;

  • •

    adversarial loss

    ℒadvTP=1N​∑n=1N−log⁡DϕTP​(GθTP​(𝐱n));subscriptsuperscriptℒTPadv1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐷TPitalic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃subscript𝐱𝑛\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\mathrm{adv}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}-\log D^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\phi}(G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}_{n}));
  • •

    identity preserving loss

    ℒipTP=∑l1Wl×Hl​∑i=1Wl∑j=1Hl|Fl​(GθTP​(𝐱))i,j−Fl​(𝐱gt)i,j|,subscriptsuperscriptℒTPipsubscript𝑙1subscript𝑊𝑙subscript𝐻𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑊𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐻𝑙superscript𝐹𝑙subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐺TP𝜃𝐱𝑖𝑗superscript𝐹𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝐱gt𝑖𝑗\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\mathrm{ip}}=\sum_{l}\frac{1}{W_{l}\times H_{l}}\sum_{i=1}^{W_{l}}\sum_{j=1}^{H_{l}}\left|F^{l}(G^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\theta}(\mathbf{x}))_{i,j}-F^{l}(\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{gt}})_{i,j}\right|,

    where Flsuperscript𝐹𝑙F^{l} denotes the output of the l𝑙lth layer of a face recognition network applied to 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and 𝐱gtsuperscript𝐱gt\mathbf{x}^{\mathrm{gt}} (Huang et al. used Light CNN [646], and only used its last two layers in ℒipTPsubscriptsuperscriptℒTPip\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\mathrm{ip}}); this idea is based on perceptual losses [287], a popular idea in GANs designed to preserve high-level features when doing low-level transformations; in this case, it serves to preserve the person’s identity when rotating the face.

As usual, the final loss function is a linear combination of the four losses above and a regularization term.

In [708], Zhao et al. propose the DA-GAN (Dual-Agent GAN) model that also works with faces but in the opposite scenario: while TP-GAN rotates every face into the frontal view, DA-GAN aims to fill in the “holes” in the real data distribution, rotating real faces so that the distribution of angles becomes more uniform. They begin with a 3D morphable model (see also Section 2.3) from [716], extracting 68 facial landmarks with the Recurrent Attentive-Refinement (RAR) model [655] and estimating the transformation matrix with 3D-MM [61]. However, the authors report that simulation quality dramatically decreases for large yaw angles, necessitating further improvement with the DA-GAN framework.

Again, DA-GAN’s generator GθDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐺DA𝜃G^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}} maps a synthetized image to a refined one, 𝐱^S=GθDA​(𝐱S)subscript^𝐱𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐺DA𝜃subscript𝐱𝑆\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S}=G^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}). It is trained on a linear combination of three loss functions

ℒGDA=−ℒadvDA+λ1​ℒipDA+λ2​ℒppDA,subscriptsuperscriptℒDA𝐺subscriptsuperscriptℒDAadvsubscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒDAipsubscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptℒDApp\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{G}=-\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{adv}}+\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{ip}}+\lambda_{2}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{pp}},

and the discriminator DϕDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕD^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}} consists of two parallel branches (agents) that optimize ℒadvDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDAadv\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{adv}} and ℒipDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDAip\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{ip}} respectively. The loss functions are defined as follows:

  • •

    the adversarial loss ℒadvDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDAadv\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{adv}} follows the BEGAN architecture introduced in [54]: this branch of DϕDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕD^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}} is an autoencoder that minimizes the Wasserstein distance with a boundary equilibrium regularization term:

    ℒadvDA=∑j|𝐱T,j−DϕDA​(𝐱T)j|−kt​∑i|𝐱^S,i−DϕDA​(𝐱^S)i|,subscriptsuperscriptℒDAadvsubscript𝑗subscript𝐱𝑇𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑇𝑗subscript𝑘𝑡subscript𝑖subscript^𝐱𝑆𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscriptsubscript^𝐱𝑆𝑖\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{adv}}=\sum_{j}\left|\mathbf{x}_{T,j}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})_{j}\right|-k_{t}\sum_{i}\left|\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,i}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S})_{i}\right|,

    where, again, 𝐱Tsubscript𝐱𝑇\mathbf{x}_{T} is a real image, 𝐱^Ssubscript^𝐱𝑆\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S} is a refined image, and ktsubscript𝑘𝑡k_{t} is a boundary equilibrium regularization term continuously trained to maintain the equilibrium

    𝔼​[∑i|𝐱^S,i−DϕDA​(𝐱^S)i|]=γ​𝔼​[∑j|𝐱T,j−DϕDA​(𝐱T)j|]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑖subscript^𝐱𝑆𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscriptsubscript^𝐱𝑆𝑖𝛾𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑗subscript𝐱𝑇𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑇𝑗{\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{i}\left|\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,i}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S})_{i}\right|\right]=\gamma{\mathbb{E}}\left[\sum_{j}\left|\mathbf{x}_{T,j}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})_{j}\right|\right]

    for some diversity ratio γ𝛾\gamma (see [54, 708] for more details); in general, ℒadvDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDAadv\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{adv}} is designed to keep the refined face in the manifold of real faces;

  • •

    the identity preservation loss ℒipDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDAip\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{ip}}, similar to ℒipTPsubscriptsuperscriptℒTPip\mathcal{L}^{\mathrm{TP}}_{\mathrm{ip}}, aims to make the refinement respect the identities, but does it in a different way; here the idea is to put both 𝐱Tsubscript𝐱𝑇\mathbf{x}_{T} and 𝐱Ssubscript𝐱𝑆\mathbf{x}_{S} through the same (relatively simple) face recognition network and bring its features together; DA-GAN uses for this purpose a classifier CϕDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐶DAitalic-ϕC^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}} trained on the bottleneck layer of DϕDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕD^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}:

    ℒipDA=subscriptsuperscriptℒDAipabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{ip}}= 1N​∑j[−𝐲j​log⁡CϕDA​(𝐱T,j)+(1−𝐲j)​log⁡(1−CϕDA​(𝐱T,j))]1𝑁subscript𝑗delimited-[]subscript𝐲𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐶DAitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑇𝑗1subscript𝐲𝑗1subscriptsuperscript𝐶DAitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑇𝑗\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j}\left[-\mathbf{y}_{j}\log C^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T,j})+(1-\mathbf{y}_{j})\log(1-C^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T,j}))\right]
    +\displaystyle+ 1N​∑j[−𝐲j​log⁡CϕDA​(𝐱^S,j)+(1−𝐲j)​log⁡(1−CϕDA​(𝐱^S,j))],1𝑁subscript𝑗delimited-[]subscript𝐲𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐶DAitalic-ϕsubscript^𝐱𝑆𝑗1subscript𝐲𝑗1subscriptsuperscript𝐶DAitalic-ϕsubscript^𝐱𝑆𝑗\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j}\left[-\mathbf{y}_{j}\log C^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,j})+(1-\mathbf{y}_{j})\log(1-C^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,j}))\right],

    where 𝐲jsubscript𝐲𝑗\mathbf{y}_{j} is the ground truth label;

  • •

    the pixel-wise loss ℒppDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDApp\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{pp}} is the L1subscript𝐿1L_{1}-loss intended to make sure that the pose (angle of inclination for the head) remains the same after refinement:

    ℒppDA=1W×H​∑i=1W∑j=1H|𝐱S,i,j−𝐱^S,i,j|.subscriptsuperscriptℒDApp1𝑊𝐻superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐻subscript𝐱𝑆𝑖𝑗subscript^𝐱𝑆𝑖𝑗\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{pp}}=\frac{1}{W\times H}\sum_{i=1}^{W}\sum_{j=1}^{H}\left|\mathbf{x}_{S,{}i,j}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,{}i,j}\right|.

In total, during training DA-GAN alternatively optimizes GθDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐺DA𝜃G^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}} and DϕDAsubscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕD^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}} with loss functions ℒGDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDA𝐺\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{G} and ℒDDA=ℒadvDA+λ1​ℒipDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒDA𝐷subscriptsuperscriptℒDAadvsubscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒDAip\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{D}=\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{adv}}+\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{ip}}. Following [54], to measure convergence DA-GAN tests the reconstruction quality together with proportion control theory, evaluating

ℒconDA=∑j|𝐱T,j−DϕDA​(𝐱T,j)|+|γ​∑j|𝐱T,j−DϕDA​(𝐱T,j)|−∑i|𝐱^S,j−DϕDA​(𝐱^S,j)||.subscriptsuperscriptℒDAconsubscript𝑗subscript𝐱𝑇𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑇𝑗𝛾subscript𝑗subscript𝐱𝑇𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑇𝑗subscript𝑖subscript^𝐱𝑆𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐷DAitalic-ϕsubscript^𝐱𝑆𝑗\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathrm{con}}=\sum_{j}\left|\mathbf{x}_{T,j}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T,j})\right|+\left|\gamma\sum_{j}\left|\mathbf{x}_{T,j}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T,j})\right|-\sum_{i}\left|\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,j}-D^{\textsc{DA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S,j})\right|\right|.

Apart from experiments done by the authors, DA-GAN was verified in a large-scale NIST IJB-A competition [171] where a model based on DA-GAN won the face verification and face identification tracks. This result heavily supports the general premise of using synthetic data: augmenting the dataset and balancing out the training data distribution with synthetic images proved highly beneficial in this case.

Inoue et al. [273] try to find a middle ground between synthetic and real data. They use two variational autoencoders (VAE) to reduce both synthetic and real data to a common pseudo-synthetic image space, and then train CNNs on images from this common space. The training sequence is as follows:

  • •

    train VAE1:𝒳S→𝒳S:subscriptVAE1→subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑆\mathrm{VAE}_{1}:\mathcal{X}_{S}\to\mathcal{X}_{S} as an autoencoder;

  • •

    train VAE2:𝒳T→𝒳S:subscriptVAE2→subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆\mathrm{VAE}_{2}:\mathcal{X}_{T}\to\mathcal{X}_{S} where the decoder is fixed and shares weights with the decoder from VAE1subscriptVAE1\mathrm{VAE}_{1}; as a result, VAE2subscriptVAE2\mathrm{VAE}_{2} has to learn to generate pseudo-synthetic images from real images;

  • •

    train a CNN for the task in question on synthetic data, using VAE1subscriptVAE1\mathrm{VAE}_{1} to map it to the common image space;

  • •

    during inference, use a composition of VAE2subscriptVAE2\mathrm{VAE}_{2} and CNN.

In the context of robotics, this kind of real-to-sim approach was continued by Zhang et al. [690] in a framework called “VR-Goggles for Robots”. It is based on the CycleGAN ideas as they were continued in CyCADA [249], a popular domain adaptation model that adds semantic losses to CycleGAN. The VR-Goggles model has two generators, GSVRG:𝒳T→𝒳S:subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆→subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}:\mathcal{X}_{T}\to\mathcal{X}_{S} with discriminator DSVRGsubscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑆D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S} that distinguishes fake synthetic images and GTVRG:𝒳S→𝒳T:subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇→subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}:\mathcal{X}_{S}\to\mathcal{X}_{T} with discriminator DTVRGsubscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑇D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T} that is defined in the domain of real images. The overall loss function is

ℒVRG=superscriptℒVRGabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}= ℒGANVRG​(GTVRG,DTVRG;𝒳S,𝒳T)+ℒGANVRG​(GSVRG,DSVRG;𝒳T,𝒳S)subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGGANsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGGANsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T},D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T};\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{T})+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S},D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{T},\mathcal{X}_{S})
+\displaystyle+ λ1​(ℒcycVRG​(GSVRG,GTVRG;𝒳T)+ℒcycVRG​(GTVRG,GSVRG;𝒳S))subscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGcycsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝒳𝑇subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGcycsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑆\displaystyle\lambda_{1}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S},G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T};\mathcal{X}_{T})+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T},G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{S})\right)
+\displaystyle+ λ2​(ℒsemVRG​(GSVRG;𝒳T,fSVRG)+ℒsemVRG​(GSVRG;𝒳S,fSVRG))subscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGsemsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGsemsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆\displaystyle\lambda_{2}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{sem}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{T},f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S})+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{sem}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{S},f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S})\right)
+\displaystyle+ λ3​(ℒshiftVRG​(GTVRG;𝒳S)+ℒshiftVRG​(GSVRG;𝒳T)), wheresubscript𝜆3subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGshiftsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGshiftsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇 where\displaystyle\lambda_{3}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{shift}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T};\mathcal{X}_{S})+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{shift}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{T})\right),\text{ where}
  • •

    ℒGANVRGsubscriptsuperscriptℒVRGGAN\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{GAN}} is the standard GAN loss:

    ℒGANVRG​(GTVRG,DTVRG;𝒳S,𝒳T)=subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGGANsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T},D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T};\mathcal{X}_{S},\mathcal{X}_{T})= 𝔼𝐱T∼preal​[log⁡DTVRG​(𝐱T)]+limit-fromsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝realdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}}\left[\log D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right]+
    𝔼𝐱S∼psyn,𝐳​[log⁡(1−DTVRG​(GTVRG​(𝐱S)))]subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syn𝐳delimited-[]1subscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝐱𝑆\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}},\mathbf{z}}\left[\log\left(1-D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))\right)\right]

    and similarly for ℒGANVRG​(GSVRG,DSVRG;𝒳T,𝒳S)subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGGANsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐷VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S},D^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{T},\mathcal{X}_{S});

  • •

    ℒsemVRGsubscriptsuperscriptℒVRGsem\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{sem}} is the semantic loss as introduced in CyCADA [249]; the idea is that if we have ground truth labels for the synthetic domain 𝒳Ssubscript𝒳𝑆\mathcal{X}_{S} (in this case, we are doing semantic segmentation), we can train a network fSVRGsubscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S} on 𝒳Ssubscript𝒳𝑆\mathcal{X}_{S} and then use it to generate pseudolabels for the domain 𝒳Tsubscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}_{T} where ground truth is not available; the semantic loss now makes sure that the results (segmentation maps) remain the same after image translation:

    ℒsemVRG​(GSVRG;𝒳T,fSVRG)subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGsemsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{sem}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{T},f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}) =𝔼𝐱T∼preal​[CE​(fSVRG​(𝐱T),fSVRG​(GSVRG​(𝐱T)))],absentsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝realdelimited-[]CEsubscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆subscript𝐱𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝐱𝑇\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}}\left[\mathrm{CE}\left(f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{T}),f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{T}))\right)\right],
    ℒsemVRG​(GTVRG;𝒳S,fSVRG)subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGsemsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{sem}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T};\mathcal{X}_{S},f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}) =𝔼𝐱S∼psyn​[CE​(fSVRG​(𝐱S),fSVRG​(GTVRG​(𝐱S)))],absentsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syndelimited-[]CEsubscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑓VRG𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝐱𝑆\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}}}\left[\mathrm{CE}\left(f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}),f^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))\right)\right],

    where CECE\mathrm{CE} denotes cross-entropy;

  • •

    ℒshiftVRGsubscriptsuperscriptℒVRGshift\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{shift}} is the shift loss that makes the image translation result invariant to shifts:

    ℒshiftVRG​(GTVRG;𝒳S)subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGshiftsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝒳𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{shift}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T};\mathcal{X}_{S}) =𝔼𝐱S,i,j​[‖GTVRG​(𝐱S)[x→iy→j]−GTVRG​(𝐱S,[x→iy→j])‖22],absentsubscript𝔼subscript𝐱𝑆𝑖𝑗delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑆delimited-[]→𝑥𝑖→𝑦𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑇subscript𝐱𝑆delimited-[]→𝑥𝑖→𝑦𝑗22\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S},i,j}\left[\left\|G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{S})_{\left[\begin{smallmatrix}x\to i\\ y\to j\end{smallmatrix}\right]}-G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{T}\left(\mathbf{x}_{S,\left[\begin{smallmatrix}x\to i\\ y\to j\end{smallmatrix}\right]}\right)\right\|^{2}_{2}\right],
    ℒshiftVRG​(GSVRG;𝒳T)subscriptsuperscriptℒVRGshiftsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝒳𝑇\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{VRG}}_{\mathrm{shift}}(G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S};\mathcal{X}_{T}) =𝔼𝐱T,i,j​[‖GSVRG​(𝐱T)[x→iy→j]−GSVRG​(𝐱T,[x→iy→j])‖22],absentsubscript𝔼subscript𝐱𝑇𝑖𝑗delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑇delimited-[]→𝑥𝑖→𝑦𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐺VRG𝑆subscript𝐱𝑇delimited-[]→𝑥𝑖→𝑦𝑗22\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T},i,j}\left[\left\|G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{T})_{\left[\begin{smallmatrix}x\to i\\ y\to j\end{smallmatrix}\right]}-G^{\textsc{VRG}}_{S}\left(\mathbf{x}_{T,\left[\begin{smallmatrix}x\to i\\ y\to j\end{smallmatrix}\right]}\right)\right\|^{2}_{2}\right],

    where 𝐱[x→iy→j]subscript𝐱delimited-[]→𝑥𝑖→𝑦𝑗\mathbf{x}_{\left[\begin{smallmatrix}x\to i\\ y\to j\end{smallmatrix}\right]} denotes the shifting operation by i𝑖i pixels along the X-axis and j𝑗j pixels along the Y-axis, and i𝑖i and j𝑗j are chosen uniformly at random up to the total downsampling factor of the network K𝐾K (since the result will always be invariant to shifts of multiples of K𝐾K).

Zhang et al. test their solution on the CARLA navigation benchmark [153] and show significant improvements.

James et al. [279] consider the same kind of approach for robotic grasping. Their model, Randomized-to-Canonical Adaptation Networks (RCAN), learn to map heavily randomized simulation images (with random textures) to a canonical (much simpler) rendered image and also map real images to canonical rendered images; interestingly, they achieve good results with a much simpler GAN architecture where additional losses simply bring together the segmentation masks and depth maps for simulated images, and there are no cycle consistency losses. An even simpler approach is taken by Yang et al. [668] who introduce domain unification for autonomous driving. Their model, called DU-Drive, consists of a generator that translates real images to simplified synthetic images and a discriminator that distinguishes them from actual synthetic images; the driving policy is then trained in the simulator.

Another idea for generating synthetic data from real is to compose parts of real images to produce synthetic ones. We have discussed the cut-and-paste approaches in 5.3; a natural continuation of these ideas would be to use more complex, semantic conditioning with a GAN-based architecture. For example, Joo et al. [293] provide a GAN-based architecture for generating a fusion image, where, say, one input 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} provides the identity of a person, another input 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} provides the shape (pose) of a person, and the result is 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} which has the identity of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and the shape of 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}. Their FusionGAN architecture extends CycleGAN-like ideas to losses that distinguish between identity and shape of an image, introduceing the concepts of identity loss and shape loss. FusionGAN relies on a dataset where there are several images with different shapes but the same identity (e.g., the same person in different poses; a dataset of videos would provide a simple example); its overall loss function is

ℒFus=ℒIFus+λ​ℒSFus, wheresuperscriptℒFussubscriptsuperscriptℒFus𝐼𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℒFus𝑆 where\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}=\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{I}+\lambda\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{S},\text{ where}
  • •

    ℒIFussubscriptsuperscriptℒFus𝐼\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{I} is the identity loss

    ℒIFus​(GFus,DFus)=subscriptsuperscriptℒFus𝐼superscript𝐺Fussuperscript𝐷Fusabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{I}(G^{\textsc{Fus}},D^{\textsc{Fus}})= 𝔼𝐱,𝐱′∼preal​(𝐱)​[‖1−DFus​(𝐱,𝐱′)‖2]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝐱′subscript𝑝real𝐱delimited-[]subscriptnorm1superscript𝐷Fus𝐱superscript𝐱′2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{x})}\left[\left\|1-D^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime})\right\|_{2}\right]
    +\displaystyle+ 𝔼𝐱∼preal​(𝐱),𝐲∼preal​(𝐲)​[‖DFus​(𝐱,GFus​(𝐱,𝐲))‖2],subscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑝real𝐱similar-to𝐲subscript𝑝real𝐲delimited-[]subscriptnormsuperscript𝐷Fus𝐱superscript𝐺Fus𝐱𝐲2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{x}),\mathbf{y}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{y})}\left[\left\|D^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))\right\|_{2}\right],

    i.e., the discriminator DFussuperscript𝐷FusD^{\textsc{Fus}} learns to distinguish real pairs of images (𝐱,𝐱′)𝐱superscript𝐱′(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}) with the same identity (but different shapes) and fake pairs of images (𝐱,GFus​(𝐱,𝐲))𝐱superscript𝐺Fus𝐱𝐲(\mathbf{x},G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})) where GFussuperscript𝐺FusG^{\textsc{Fus}} is supposed to take the identity from 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x};

  • •

    ℒSFussubscriptsuperscriptℒFus𝑆\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{S} is the shape loss defined as

    ℒS1Fus​(GFus)=𝔼𝐱,𝐱′∼preal​(𝐱)​[‖𝐱′−GFus​(𝐱,𝐱′)‖1]subscriptsuperscriptℒFussubscript𝑆1superscript𝐺Fussubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱superscript𝐱′subscript𝑝real𝐱delimited-[]subscriptnormsuperscript𝐱′superscript𝐺Fus𝐱superscript𝐱′1\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{S_{1}}(G^{\textsc{Fus}})={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{x})}\left[\left\|\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x}^{\prime})\right\|_{1}\right]

    when 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and 𝐱′superscript𝐱′\mathbf{x}^{\prime} have the same identity, and

    ℒS2​aFus​(GFus)subscriptsuperscriptℒFussubscript𝑆2𝑎superscript𝐺Fus\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{S_{2}a}(G^{\textsc{Fus}}) =𝔼𝐱∼preal​(𝐱),𝐲∼preal​(𝐲)​[‖𝐲−GFus​(𝐲,GFus​(𝐱,𝐲))‖1],absentsubscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝐱subscript𝑝real𝐱similar-to𝐲subscript𝑝real𝐲delimited-[]subscriptnorm𝐲superscript𝐺Fus𝐲superscript𝐺Fus𝐱𝐲1\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{x}),\mathbf{y}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{y})}\left[\left\|\mathbf{y}-G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{y},G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))\right\|_{1}\right],
    ℒS2​bFus​(GFus)subscriptsuperscriptℒFussubscript𝑆2𝑏superscript𝐺Fus\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Fus}}_{S_{2}b}(G^{\textsc{Fus}}) =𝔼𝐱∼preal​(𝐱),𝐲∼preal​(𝐲)[∥GFus(𝐱,𝐲)−GFus(GFus(𝐱,𝐲),𝐲))∥1],\displaystyle={\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{x}),\mathbf{y}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}(\mathbf{y})}\left[\left\|G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})-G^{\textsc{Fus}}(G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}),\mathbf{y}))\right\|_{1}\right],

    i.e., GFus​(𝐲,GFus​(𝐱,𝐲))superscript𝐺Fus𝐲superscript𝐺Fus𝐱𝐲G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{y},G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})) should be the same as 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}, with identity from 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} and shape also from 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}, and GFus(GFus(𝐱,𝐲),𝐲))G^{\textsc{Fus}}(G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}),\mathbf{y})) should be the same as GFus​(𝐱,𝐲)superscript𝐺Fus𝐱𝐲G^{\textsc{Fus}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}), with identity from 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and shape from 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}.

Similar ideas have been extended to animating still images [547], motion transfer [90], and image-to-image translation [384]. In general, these works belong to an interesting field of generative semantic manipulation with GANs. Important works in this direction include Mask-Contrasting GAN [358] that can modify an object to a different suitable category inside its segmentation mask (e.g., replace a cat with a dog), Attention-GAN [105] that performs the same task with an attention-based architecture, IterGAN [186] that attempts iterative small-scale 3D manipulations such as rotation from 2D images, and others. However, while this field produces very interesting works, so far we have not seen direct applications of such architectures to generating synthetic data. We believe that ideas similar to TP-GAN can also be fruitful in other domains, especially in situations where one- or few-shot learning is required so “smart augmentations” such as rotation can bring significant improvements.

6.2 Domain adaptation at the feature/model level

In the previous sections, we have considered models that perform domain adaptation (DA) at the data level, i.e., one can extract a part of the model that takes as input a data point from the source domain (in our case, a synthetic image) and map it to the target domain (domain of real images). However, the final goal of model design rarely involves the generation of more realistic synthetic images; they are merely a stepping stone to producing models that work better, e.g., in the absence of supervision in the target domain. Therefore, to make better use of synthetic data it makes sense to also consider feature-level or model-level domain adaptation, i.e., methods that work in the space of features or model weights and never go back to change the actual data.

The simplest approach to domain adaptation would be to share the weights between networks operating on different domains or learn an explicit mapping between them [118, 203]. While we mostly discuss other approaches, we note that simpler techniques based on weight sharing remain relevant for domain adaptation. In particular, Rozantsev et al. [504] recently presented a domain adaptation approach where two similar networks are trained on the source and target domain with special regularizers that bring their weights together; the authors evaluate their approach on synthetic-to-real domain adaptation for drone detection with promising results.

Another approach to model-level domain adaptation is related to mining relatively strong priors from real data that can then inform a model trained on synthetic data, helping fix problematic cases or incongruencies between the synthetic and real datasets. For example, Zhang et al. [699, 698] present a curriculum learning approach to domain adaptation for semantic segmentation of urban scenes. They train a segmentation network on synthetic data (specifically on the GTA dataset; see also Section 3.1) but with a special component in the loss function related to the general label distribution in real images:

ℒCurr=1|𝒳S|​∑𝐱S∈𝒳Sℒ​(𝐲S,𝐲^S)+λ​1|𝒳T|​∑𝐱T∈𝒳T∑k𝒞​(pk​(𝐱T),p^k​(𝐱T)),superscriptℒCurr1subscript𝒳𝑆subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝒳𝑆ℒsubscript𝐲𝑆subscript^𝐲𝑆𝜆1subscript𝒳𝑇subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝒳𝑇subscript𝑘𝒞superscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐱𝑇superscript^𝑝𝑘subscript𝐱𝑇\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{Curr}}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{X}_{S}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\in\mathcal{X}_{S}}\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbf{y}_{S},\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{S}\right)+\lambda\frac{1}{|\mathcal{X}_{T}|}\sum_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\in\mathcal{X}_{T}}\sum_{k}{\mathcal{C}}\left(p^{k}(\mathbf{x}_{T}),{\hat{p}}^{k}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right),

where ℒ​(𝐲S,𝐲^S)ℒsubscript𝐲𝑆subscript^𝐲𝑆\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbf{y}_{S},\hat{\mathbf{y}}_{S}\right) is the pixel-wise cross-entropy, a standard segmentation loss, and 𝒞​(pk​(𝐱T),p^k​(𝐱T))𝒞superscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐱𝑇superscript^𝑝𝑘subscript𝐱𝑇{\mathcal{C}}\left(p^{k}(\mathbf{x}_{T}),{\hat{p}}^{k}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right) is the cross-entropy between the distribution of labels p^​(𝐱T)^𝑝subscript𝐱𝑇{\hat{p}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}) in a real image 𝐱Tsubscript𝐱𝑇\mathbf{x}_{T} that the network produces and p​(𝐱T)𝑝subscript𝐱𝑇p(\mathbf{x}_{T}) is the real label distribution (superscript k𝑘k denotes different kinds of label distributions). Note that p​(𝐱T)𝑝subscript𝐱𝑇p(\mathbf{x}_{T}) is not available in the real data, so this is where curriculum learning comes in: the authors first train on synthetic a simpler model to estimate p​(𝐱T)𝑝subscript𝐱𝑇p(\mathbf{x}_{T}) from image features and then use it to inform the segmentation model. Recent developments of this interesting direction shift from merely enforcing the label distribution to matching features on multiple different levels [263]. In particular, recent works [357, 680] have introduced the so-called pyramid consistency loss instead of 𝒞​(p​(𝐱T),p^​(𝐱T))𝒞𝑝subscript𝐱𝑇^𝑝subscript𝐱𝑇{\mathcal{C}}\left(p(\mathbf{x}_{T}),{\hat{p}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right) that tries to enforce consistency across domains on the activation maps of later layers of the network.

One of the main directions in model-level domain adaptation was initiated by Ganin and Lempitsky [190] who present a generic framework for unsupervised domain adaptation. Their approach, illustrated on Figure 21, consists of a feature extractor, a label predictor that performs the necessary task (e.g., classification) on extracted features, and a domain classifier that takes the same features and attempts to classify which domain the original input belonged to. The idea is to train the label predictor to perform as well as possible and at the same time train the domain classifier to perform as badly as possible; this is achieved with gradient reversal, i.e., multiplying the gradients by a negative constant as they pass from the domain classifier to the feature extractor. In a subsequent work, Ganin et al. [191] generalized this domain adaptation approach to arbitrary architectures and experimented with DA in different domains, including image classification, person re-identification, and sentiment analysis. We also note extensions and similar approaches to domain adaptation developed in [376, 603, 377] and the domain confusion metric that helps produce domain-invariant representation [604], but proceed to highlight the works that perform specifically synthetic-to-real domain adaptation.

Many general model-level domain adaptation approaches have been validated or subsequently extended to synthetic-to-real domain adaptation. Xu et al. [664] consider the pedestrian detection problem (this work is a continuation of [612], see Section 2.2.2). They adapt detectors trained on virtual datasets with a boosting-based procedure, assigning larger weights to samples that are similar to target domain ones. Sun and Saenko [567] propose a domain adaptation approach based on decorrelating the features of a classifier, both in unsupervised and supervised settings. Later, López et al. [378] extended the SA-SVVM domain adaptation used in [612] to train deformable part-based models, using synthetic pedestrians from the SYNTHIA dataset (see Section 3.1) as the main example. In a parallel paper, the authors of SYNTHIA Ros et al. [500] used a simple domain adaptation technique called Balanced Gradient Contribution [501], where training on synthetic data is regularized by the gradient obtained on a (small) real dataset, to further improve their results on segmentation aided by synthetic data. Ren et al. [490] perform cross-domain self-supervised multi-task learning with synthetic images: their model predicts several parameters of an image (surface normal, depth, and instance contour) and at the same time tries to minimize the difference between synthetic and real data in feature space.

Domain separation networks by Bousmalis et al. [72], illustrated on Fig. 22, explicitly separate the shared and private components of both source and target domains. Specifically, they introduce a shared encoder EDSN​(𝐱)superscript𝐸DSN𝐱E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}) and two private encoders, ESDSNsubscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑆E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{S} for the source domain and ETDSNsubscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑇E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{T} for the target domain. The total objective function for a domain separation network is

ℒDSN=ℒtaskDSN+λ1​ℒrecDSN+λ2​ℒdiffDSN+λ1​ℒsimDSN, wheresuperscriptℒDSNsubscriptsuperscriptℒDSNtasksubscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒDSNrecsubscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptℒDSNdiffsubscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒDSNsim where\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}=\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{task}}+\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{rec}}+\lambda_{2}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{diff}}+\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{sim}},\text{ where}
  • •

    ℒtaskDSNsubscriptsuperscriptℒDSNtask\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{task}} is the supervised task loss in the source domain, e.g., for the image classification task it is

    ℒtaskDSN=−𝔼𝐱S∼psyn​[𝐲⊤​log⁡fDSN​(EDSN​(𝐱S))],subscriptsuperscriptℒDSNtasksubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syndelimited-[]superscript𝐲topsuperscript𝑓DSNsuperscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑆\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{task}}=-{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}}}\left[\mathbf{y}^{\top}\log f^{\textsc{DSN}}(E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))\right],

    where fDSNsuperscript𝑓DSNf^{\textsc{DSN}} is the classifier operating on the output of the shared encoder;

  • •

    ℒrecDSNsubscriptsuperscriptℒDSNrec\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{rec}} is the reconstruction loss defined as the difference between the original samples 𝐱Ssubscript𝐱𝑆\mathbf{x}_{S} and 𝐱Tsubscript𝐱𝑇\mathbf{x}_{T} and the results of a shared decoder DDSNsuperscript𝐷DSND^{\textsc{DSN}} that tries to reconstruct the images from a combination of shared and private representations:

    ℒrecDSN=subscriptsuperscriptℒDSNrecabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{rec}}= −𝔼𝐱S∼psyn​[ℒsim​(𝐱S,DDSN​(EDSN​(𝐱S)+ESDSN​(𝐱S)))]subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syndelimited-[]subscriptℒsimsubscript𝐱𝑆superscript𝐷DSNsuperscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆\displaystyle-{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}}}\left[\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{sim}}(\mathbf{x}_{S},D^{\textsc{DSN}}(E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{S})+E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S})))\right]
    −𝔼𝐱T∼preal​[ℒsim​(𝐱T,DDSN​(EDSN​(𝐱T)+ETDSN​(𝐱T)))]subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝realdelimited-[]subscriptℒsimsubscript𝐱𝑇superscript𝐷DSNsuperscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇\displaystyle-{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}}\left[\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{sim}}(\mathbf{x}_{T},D^{\textsc{DSN}}(E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})+E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{T})))\right]

    for some similarity metric ℒsimsubscriptℒsim\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{sim}};

  • •

    ℒdiffDSNsubscriptsuperscriptℒDSNdiff\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{diff}} is the difference loss that encourages the hidden shared representations of instances from the source and target domains EDSN​(𝐱S)superscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑆E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}) and EDSN​(𝐱T)superscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑇E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}) to be orthogonal to their corresponding private representations ESDSN​(𝐱S)subscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}) and ETDSN​(𝐱T)subscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{T}); in [72], the difference loss is defined as

    ℒdiffDSN=‖HS⊤​HSpri‖F2+‖HT⊤​HTpri‖F2,subscriptsuperscriptℒDSNdiffsubscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑆topsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑆pri2𝐹subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑇topsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑇pri2𝐹\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{diff}}=\left\|H_{S}^{\top}H_{S}^{\mathrm{pri}}\right\|^{2}_{F}+\left\|H_{T}^{\top}H_{T}^{\mathrm{pri}}\right\|^{2}_{F},

    where HSsubscript𝐻𝑆H_{S} is the matrix of EDSN​(𝐱S)superscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑆E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}), HSprisuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑆priH_{S}^{\mathrm{pri}} is the matrix of ESDSN​(𝐱S)subscriptsuperscript𝐸DSN𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆E^{\textsc{DSN}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}), and similarly for HTsubscript𝐻𝑇H_{T} and HTprisuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑇priH_{T}^{\mathrm{pri}};

  • •

    ℒsimDSNsubscriptsuperscriptℒDSNsim\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{DSN}}_{\mathrm{sim}} is the similarity loss that encourages the hidden shared representations from the source and target domains EDSN​(𝐱S)superscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑆E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}) and EDSN​(𝐱T)superscript𝐸DSNsubscript𝐱𝑇E^{\textsc{DSN}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}) to be similar to each other, i.e., indistinguishable by a domain classifier trained through the gradient reversal layer as in [190]; in [72], this loss is composed of the cross-entropy for the domain classifier and maximal mean discrepancy (MMD) [211] for the hidden representations themselves.

Bousmalis et al. evaluate their model on several synthetic-to-real scenarios, e.g., on synthetic traffic signs from [416] and synthetic objects from the LineMod dataset [638].

Domain separation networks became one of the first major examples in domain adaptation with disentanglement, where the hidden representations are domain-invariant and some of the features can be changed to transition from one domain to another. Further developments include asymmetric training for unsupervised domain adaptation [514], DistanceGAN for one-sided domain mapping [52], co-regularized alignment [334], cross-domain autoencoders [206], multisource domain adversarial networks [705], continuous cross-domain translation [367], face recognition adaptation from images to videos with the help of synthetic augmentations [554], and more [689]; all of these advances may be relevant for synthetic-to-real domain adaptation but we will highlight some works that are already doing adaptation between these two domains.

The popular and important domains for feature-based domain adaptation are more or less the same as in domain adaptation on the data level, but feature-based DA may be able to handle higher-dimensional inputs and more complex scenes because the adaptation itself is done in an intermediate lower-dimensional space. As an illustrative example, let us consider feature-based DA for computer vision problems for outdoor scenes (see also Section 3.1). In their FCNs in the Wild model, Hoffman et al. [250] consider feature-based DA for semantic segmentation with fully convolutional networks (FCN) where ground truth is available for the source domain (synthetic data) but unavailable for the target domain (real data). Their unsupervised domain adaptation framework contains a feature extractor fFCNWsuperscript𝑓FCNWf^{\textsc{FCNW}} and the joint objective function

ℒFCNW=ℒsegFCNW+ℒDAFCNW+ℒMIFCNW, wheresuperscriptℒFCNWsubscriptsuperscriptℒFCNWsegsubscriptsuperscriptℒFCNWDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒFCNWMI where\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}=\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}_{\mathrm{seg}}+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}_{\mathrm{DA}}+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}_{\mathrm{MI}},\text{ where}
  • •

    ℒsegFCNWsubscriptsuperscriptℒFCNWseg\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}_{\mathrm{seg}} is the standard supervised segmentation objective on the source domain, where supervision is available;

  • •

    ℒDAFCNWsubscriptsuperscriptℒFCNWDA\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}_{\mathrm{DA}} is the domain alignment objective that minimizes the observed source and target distance in the representation space by training a discriminator (domain classifier) to distinguish instances from source and target domains; an interesting new idea here is to take as an instance for this objective not the entire image but a cell from a coarse grid that corresponds to the of high-level features that domain adaptation is supposed to bring together;

  • •

    ℒMIFCNWsubscriptsuperscriptℒFCNWMI\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{FCNW}}_{\mathrm{MI}} is the multiple instance loss that encourages pixels to be assigned to class c𝑐c in such a way that the percentage of an image labeled with c𝑐c remains withing the expected range derived from the source domain.

Another direction of increasing the input dimension is to move from images to videos. Xu et al. [663] use adversarial domain adaptation to transfer object detection models—single-shot multi-box detector (SSD) [372] and multi-scale deep CNN (MSCNN) [81]—from synthetic samples to real videos in the smoke detection problem.

Chen et al. [107] construct the Cross City Adaptation model that brings together the features from different domains, again with semantic segmentation of outdoor scenes in mind. Their framework optimizes the joint objective function

ℒCCA=ℒtaskCCA+ℒglobalCCA+ℒclassCCA, wheresuperscriptℒCCAsubscriptsuperscriptℒCCAtasksubscriptsuperscriptℒCCAglobalsubscriptsuperscriptℒCCAclass where\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}=\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}_{\mathrm{task}}+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}_{\mathrm{global}}+\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}_{\mathrm{class}},\text{ where}
  • •

    ℒtaskCCAsubscriptsuperscriptℒCCAtask\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}_{\mathrm{task}} is the task loss, in this case cross-entropy between predicted and ground truth segmentation masks in the source domain;

  • •

    ℒglobalCCAsubscriptsuperscriptℒCCAglobal\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}_{\mathrm{global}} is the global domain alignment loss, again defined as fooling the domain discriminator similar to FCNs in the Wild;

  • •

    ℒclassCCAsubscriptsuperscriptℒCCAclass\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{CCA}}_{\mathrm{class}} is the class-wise domain alignment loss, where grid cells are assigned soft class labels (extracted from the truth in the source domain and predicted in the target domain), and the domain classifiers and discriminators are trained and applied class-wise, separately.

As the title suggests, Cross City Adaptation is intended to adapt outdoor segmentation models trained on one city to other cities, but Chen et al. also apply it to synthetic-to-real domain adaptation from SYNTHIA to Cityscapes (see Section 3.1), achieving noticeable gains in segmentation quality.

Hong et al. [252] provide one of the most direct and most promising applications of feature-level synthetic-to-real domain adaptation. In their Structural Adaptation Network, the conditional generator GθSDA​(𝐱S,𝐳)subscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscript𝐱𝑆𝐳G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{S},\mathbf{z}) takes as input the features flSDA​(𝐱S)subscriptsuperscript𝑓SDA𝑙subscript𝐱𝑆f^{\textsc{SDA}}_{l}(\mathbf{x}_{S}) from a low-level layer of the feature extractor (i.e., features with fine-grained details) and random noise 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z} and produces transformed feature maps that should be simlar to feature maps extracted from real images. To achieve that, GSDAsuperscript𝐺SDAG^{\textsc{SDA}} produces a noise map G^θSDA​(flSDA​(𝐱S),𝐳)subscriptsuperscript^𝐺SDA𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝑓SDA𝑙subscript𝐱𝑆𝐳{\hat{G}}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(f^{\textsc{SDA}}_{l}(\mathbf{x}_{S}),\mathbf{z}) and then adds it to high-level features: GθSDA​(𝐱S,𝐳)=fhSDA​(𝐱S)+G^θSDA​(flSDA​(𝐱S),𝐳)subscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscript𝐱𝑆𝐳subscriptsuperscript𝑓SDAℎsubscript𝐱𝑆subscriptsuperscript^𝐺SDA𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝑓SDA𝑙subscript𝐱𝑆𝐳G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{S},\mathbf{z})=f^{\textsc{SDA}}_{h}(\mathbf{x}_{S})+{\hat{G}}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(f^{\textsc{SDA}}_{l}(\mathbf{x}_{S}),\mathbf{z}). The optimization problem is

minθ,θ′⁡maxϕ⁡(ℒGANSDA​(GθSDA,DϕSDA)+λ​ℒtaskSDA​(GθSDA,Tθ′SDA)), wheresubscript𝜃superscript𝜃′subscriptitalic-ϕsubscriptsuperscriptℒSDAGANsubscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝐷SDAitalic-ϕ𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℒSDAtasksubscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝑇SDAsuperscript𝜃′ where\min_{\mathbf{\theta},\mathbf{\theta}^{\prime}}\max_{\mathbf{\phi}}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}},D^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}})+\lambda\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathrm{task}}(G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}},T^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}^{\prime}})\right),\text{ where}
  • •

    ℒGANSDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒSDAGAN\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathrm{GAN}} is the GAN loss in the feature space:

    ℒGANSDA​(GθSDA,DϕSDA)=subscriptsuperscriptℒSDAGANsubscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝐷SDAitalic-ϕabsent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathrm{GAN}}(G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}},D^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}})= 𝔼𝐱T∼preal​[log⁡DϕSDA​(𝐱T)]+limit-fromsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝑝realdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐷SDAitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑇\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim p_{\mathrm{real}}}\left[\log D^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right]+
    𝔼𝐱S∼psyn,𝐳​[log⁡(1−DϕSDA​(GθSDA​(𝐱S,𝐳)))];subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝑝syn𝐳delimited-[]1subscriptsuperscript𝐷SDAitalic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscript𝐱𝑆𝐳\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim p_{\mathrm{syn}},\mathbf{z}}\left[\log\left(1-D^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\phi}}(G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{S},\mathbf{z}))\right)\right];
  • •

    ℒtaskSDAsubscriptsuperscriptℒSDAtask\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathrm{task}} is the task loss for the pixel-wise classifier Tθ′SDAsubscriptsuperscript𝑇SDAsuperscript𝜃′T^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}^{\prime}} which is trained end-to-end, together with the rest of the architecture; the task loss is defined as the pixel-wise cross-entropy between the segmentation mask Tθ′SDA​(GθSDA​(𝐱S,𝐳))subscriptsuperscript𝑇SDAsuperscript𝜃′subscriptsuperscript𝐺SDA𝜃subscript𝐱𝑆𝐳T^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}^{\prime}}(G^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{S},\mathbf{z})) produced by Tθ′SDAsubscriptsuperscript𝑇SDAsuperscript𝜃′T^{\textsc{SDA}}_{\mathbf{\theta}^{\prime}} on adapted features and the ground truth synthetic segmentation mask 𝐲Ssubscript𝐲𝑆\mathbf{y}_{S}.

Hong et al. compare the Structural Adaptation Network with other state of the art approaches, including FCNs in the Wild [250] and cross-city adaptation [107], with source domain datasets SYNTHIA and GTA and target domain dataset Cityscapes; they conclude that this adaptation significantly improves the results for semantic segmentation of urban scenes.

To summarize, feature-level domain adaptation provides interesting opportunities for synthetic-to-real adaptation, but these methods still mostly represent work in progress. In our experience, feature- and model-level DA is usually a simpler and more robust approach, easier to get to work, so we expect new exciting developments in this direction and recommend to try this family of methods for synthetic-to-real DA (unless actual refined images are required).

6.3 Domain adaptation for control and robotics

In the field of control, joint domain adaptation is usually intended to transfer control policies learned in a simulated environment to a real setting. As we have already discussed in Sections 3.2 and 3.1, simulated environments are almost inevitable in reinforcement learning for robotics, as they allow to scale the datasets up compared to real data and cover a much wider range of situations than real data that could be used for imitational learning (see also the survey [574]). In this setting, domain adaptation is performed either for the control itself or jointly for the control and synthetic data. The field began even before deep learning; for instance, Saxena et al. [522] learned a model for estimating grasp locations for previously unseen objects on synthetic data.

In Cutler et al. [129], the results of training on a simulator serve as a prior for subsequent learning in the real world. Moreover, in [130, 131] Cutler et al. proceed to multifidelity simulators, training the reinforcement learning agent in a series of simulators with increasing realism; we note this idea as potentially fruitful for other domains as well.

DeepMind researchers Rusu et al. [509] studied the possibility for transfer learning from simulated environments to the real world in the context of end-to-end reinforcement learning for robotics. They use the general idea of progressive networks [508], an architecture designed for multitask learning and transfer where each subsequent column in the network solves a new task and receives as input the hidden activations from previous columns. Rusu et al. present a modification of this idea for robot transfer learning, then train the first column in the MuJoCo physics simulator [589], and then transfer to a real Jaco robotic arm, using the Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C) framework for reinforcement learning [413]. The authors report improved results for progressive networks compared to simple transfer via fine-tuning.

There are plenty of works that consider similar kinds of transfer learning, known in robotics as closing the reality gap. In particular, Bousmalis et al. [70] use a simulated environment to learn robotic grasping with a domain adaptation model called GraspGAN that makes synthetic images more realistic with a refiner (see Section 6.1.2); they argue that the added realism improves the results for control transfer. Tzeng et al. [602] propose a framework that combines supervised domain adaptation (that requires paired images) and unsupervised DA (that aligns the domains on the level of distributions); to do that, they introduce the notion of a “weak pairing” between images in the source and target domains and learn to find matching synthetic images to produce aligned data. The resulting model is successfully applied to training a visuomotor policy for real robots. Pan et al. [676] consider sim-to-real translation for autonomous driving; they convert synthetic images to a scene parsing representation and then generate a realistic image by a generator corresponding to this parsing representation; the reinforcement learning agent receives this image as part of its driving environment. An even simpler approach, taken, e.g., by Xu et al [577], would be to directly use the segmentation masks as input for the RL agent.

Researchers from Wayve Bewley et el. [55] perform domain adaptation for learning to drive from simulation; they claim to present the first end-to-end driving policy transferred from an (obviously supervised) synthetic setting to the fully unsupervised real domain. Their model does image translation and control transfer at the same time, learning the control on a jointly learned latent embedding space. The architecture consists of two encoders ESwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S} and ETwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑇E^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}, two generators GSwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑆G^{\textsc{wve}}_{S} and GTwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑇G^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}, two discriminators DSwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐷wve𝑆D^{\textsc{wve}}_{S} and DTwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐷wve𝑇D^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}, and a controller Cwvesuperscript𝐶wveC^{\textsc{wve}}. The image translator follows the MUNIT architecture [370], with two convolutional variational autoencoder networks that swap the latent embeddings to translate between domains, i.e., for 𝐱S∼𝒳Ssimilar-tosubscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝒳𝑆\mathbf{x}_{S}\sim\mathcal{X}_{S}, 𝐱T∼𝒳Tsimilar-tosubscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝒳𝑇\mathbf{x}_{T}\sim\mathcal{X}_{T}

𝐳S=ESwve​(𝐱S)+ϵ,𝐱^S=GSwve​(𝐳S),𝐳T=ETwve​(𝐱T)+ϵ,𝐱^T=GTwve​(𝐳T),subscript𝐳𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆italic-ϵsubscript^𝐱𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑆subscript𝐳𝑆subscript𝐳𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇italic-ϵsubscript^𝐱𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑇subscript𝐳𝑇\begin{array}[]{cc}\mathbf{z}_{S}=E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S})+\epsilon,&\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{S}=G^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{z}_{S}),\\ \mathbf{z}_{T}=E^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{T})+\epsilon,&\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{T}=G^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(\mathbf{z}_{T}),\\ \end{array}

and the translation is to compute 𝐳Ssubscript𝐳𝑆\mathbf{z}_{S} with ESwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S} and then predict 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} with GTwvesubscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑇G^{\textsc{wve}}_{T} and vice versa. The overall generator loss function is

ℒwvesuperscriptℒwve\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}} =λ0​ℒrecwve+λ1​ℒcycwve+λ2​ℒctrlwve+λ3​ℒcyctrlwve+absentsubscript𝜆0subscriptsuperscriptℒwverecsubscript𝜆1subscriptsuperscriptℒwvecycsubscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscriptℒwvectrllimit-fromsubscript𝜆3subscriptsuperscriptℒwvecyctrl\displaystyle=\lambda_{0}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{rec}}+\lambda_{1}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}+\lambda_{2}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{ctrl}}+\lambda_{3}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{cyctrl}}+
+λ4​ℒLSGANwve+λ5​ℒpercwve+λ6​ℒzrecwve,wheresubscript𝜆4subscriptsuperscriptℒwveLSGANsubscript𝜆5subscriptsuperscriptℒwvepercsubscript𝜆6subscriptsuperscriptℒwvezrecwhere\displaystyle+\lambda_{4}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{LSGAN}}+\lambda_{5}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{perc}}+\lambda_{6}\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{zrec}},\quad\text{where}
  • •

    ℒrecwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwverec\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{rec}} is the L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} image reconstruction loss in both domains:

    ℒrecwve​(𝐱S)subscriptsuperscriptℒwverecsubscript𝐱𝑆\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{rec}}(\mathbf{x}_{S}) =‖GSwve​(ESwve​(𝐱S))−𝐱S‖1,absentsubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆1\displaystyle=\|G^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))-\mathbf{x}_{S}\|_{1},
    ℒrecwve​(𝐱T)subscriptsuperscriptℒwverecsubscript𝐱𝑇\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{rec}}(\mathbf{x}_{T}) =‖GTwve​(ETwve​(𝐱T))−𝐱T‖1;absentsubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇subscript𝐱𝑇1\displaystyle=\|G^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(\mathbf{x}_{T}))-\mathbf{x}_{T}\|_{1};
  • •

    ℒcycwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwvecyc\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{cyc}} is the cycle consistency loss for both domains:

    ℒcycwve​(𝐱S)=‖GSwve​(ETwve​(GTwve​(ESwve​(𝐱S))))−𝐱S‖1subscriptsuperscriptℒwvecycsubscript𝐱𝑆subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆1\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{cyc}}(\mathbf{x}_{S})=\|G^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(G^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))))-\mathbf{x}_{S}\|_{1}

    and similar for 𝒳Tsubscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}_{T};

  • •

    ℒctrlwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwvectrl\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{ctrl}} is the control loss that compares the controls produced on the training set with the autopilot: ℒctrlwve​(𝐱S)=‖Cwve​(ESwve​(𝐱S))−𝐜‖1subscriptsuperscriptℒwvectrlsubscript𝐱𝑆subscriptnormsuperscript𝐶wvesubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆𝐜1\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{ctrl}}(\mathbf{x}_{S})=\|C^{\textsc{wve}}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))-\mathbf{c}\|_{1} for ground truth control 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}, and similar for 𝒳Tsubscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}_{T};

  • •

    ℒcyctrlwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwvecyctrl\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{cyctrl}} is the control cycle consistency loss that makes the controls similar for images translated to another domain:

    ℒcyctrlwve​(𝐱S)=‖Cwve​(ETwve​(GSwve​(ESwve​(𝐱S))))−Cwve​(ESwve​(𝐱S))‖1,subscriptsuperscriptℒwvecyctrlsubscript𝐱𝑆subscriptnormsuperscript𝐶wvesubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆superscript𝐶wvesubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑆subscript𝐱𝑆1\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{cyctrl}}(\mathbf{x}_{S})=\|C^{\textsc{wve}}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(G^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))))-C^{\textsc{wve}}(E^{\textsc{wve}}_{S}(\mathbf{x}_{S}))\|_{1},

    and similar for 𝒳Tsubscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}_{T};

  • •

    ℒLSGANwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwveLSGAN\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{LSGAN}} is the LSGAN adversarial loss applied to both generator-discriminator pairs (see above);

  • •

    ℒpercwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwveperc\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{perc}} is the perceptual loss (see above) for both image translation directions with instance normalization applied before, as shown in [266];

  • •

    ℒzrecwvesubscriptsuperscriptℒwvezrec\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{zrec}} is the latent reconstruction loss: ℒzrecwve​(𝐳S)=‖ETwve​(GTwve​(𝐳S))−𝐳S‖1subscriptsuperscriptℒwvezrecsubscript𝐳𝑆subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐸wve𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝐺wve𝑇subscript𝐳𝑆subscript𝐳𝑆1\mathcal{L}^{\textsc{wve}}_{\mathrm{zrec}}(\mathbf{z}_{S})=\|E^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(G^{\textsc{wve}}_{T}(\mathbf{z}_{S}))-\mathbf{z}_{S}\|_{1} and similar for 𝒳Tsubscript𝒳𝑇\mathcal{X}_{T}.

Bewley et al. compare their approach with a number of transfer learning baselines, show excellent results for end-to-end learning to drive, and even perform real world experiments with the trained policy. Similar techniques have been used without synthetic data in the loop as well; e.g., Wulfmeier et al. [650] use a similar model for domain adaptation to handle appearance changes in outdoor robotics, i.e., changes in weather conditions, lighting, and the like.

We have already discussed the works of Inoue et al. [273], Zhang et al. [690], James et al. [279], and Yang et al. [668] who make real data more similar to synthetic for computer vision problems related to robotic grasping and visual navigation (see Section 6.1.3). Importantly, these models are not merely translating images but are also tested on real world robots. Zhang et al. not only show improvements in semantic segmentation results but also conduct real-world robotic experiments for indoor and outdoor visual navigation tasks, first training a navigation policy in a simulated environment and then directly deploying it on a robot in a real environment, while James et al. test their solution on a real robotic hand, training the QT-Opt policy [301] to grasp from a simulation with 5000 additional real life grasping episodes better than the same policy trained on 580,000 real episodes, a more than 99% reduction in required real world input.

Another direction where synthetic data might be useful for learning control is to generate synthetic behaviours to improve imitation learning [433]. Bansal et al. [35] discuss the insufficient data problem in imitation learning: for learning to drive, even 30 million real-world expert driving examples that combine into more than 60 days of driving is not sufficient to train an end-to-end driving model. To alleviate this lack of data, they present their imitation learning framework ChauffeurNet with data where synthetic perturbations have been introduced to expert driving examples. This allows to cover corner cases such as collisions and off-road driving, i.e., bad examples that should be avoided but that are lacking in expert examples altogether. Interestingly, perturbations are introduced into intermediate representations rather than in raw sensor input or controller outputs.

To sum up, closing the reality gap is one of the most important problems in the field of control and robotics. Important breakthroughs in this direction appear constantly, but there is still some way to go before self-driving cars and robotic arms are able to train in a simulated environment and then perfectly transfer these skills to the real world.

6.4 Case study: GAN-based domain adaptation for medical imaging

Medical imaging is a field where labeled data is especially hard to come by. First, while manual labeling is hard and expensive enough for regular computer vision problems, in medical imaging it is far more expensive because it cannot be crowdsourced to anonymous annotators: for most problems, medical imaging data can only be reliably labeled by a trained professional, often with a medical degree. Second, for obvious privacy reasons it is very hard to arrange for publishing real datasets, and collecting a large enough labeled dataset to train a standard object detection or segmentation model would in many cases require a concerted effort from several different hospitals; thus, with the exception of public competitions, most papers in the field use private datasets and are not allowed to share their data. Third, some pathologies simply do not have sufficiently large and diverse datasets collected yet. At the same time, often there are relatively large generic datasets available, e.g., of healthy tissue but not of a specific pathology of interest.

While we emphasize GAN-based generation methods, we note that there have been successful attempts to use rendered synthetic data for medical imaging tasks that are based on recent developments in medical visualization and rendering tools. For example, Mahmood et al. [388] use the recently developed cinematic rendering technique for CT [167] (a photorealistic simulation of the propagation of light through tissue) to train a CNN for depth estimation in endoscopy data.

GANs have been widely applied to generating realistic medical images [423, 326, 46, 40, 666, 673]. Moreover, since the images are domain-specific, the quality of GAN-produced images has relatively quickly reached the level where it can in many applications pass the “visual Turing test”, fooling even trained specialists; see, e.g., lung nodule samples generated in [120] or magnetic resonance (MR) images of the brain in [82, 227]. Therefore, it is no wonder that GAN-based domain adaptation (DA) techniques, especially based on fusing and augmenting real images, are increasingly finding their way into medical imaging. In this section, we give a brief overview of recent work in this domain.

In some works, synthetic data is generated from scratch, i.e., GANs are trained to convert random noise into synthetic images (see also Section 5.4). Frid-Adar et al. [181, 180] used two standard GAN architectures, Deep Convolutional GAN (DCGAN) [472] and Auxiliary Classifier GAN (ACGAN) [428] with class label auxiliary information, to generate synthetic computed tomography (CT) images of liver lesions. They report significantly improved results in image classification with CNNs when training on synthetic data compared to standard augmentations of their highly limited dataset (182 2D scans divided into three types of lesions). Baur et al. [666] attempt high resolution skin lesion synthesis, comparing several GAN architectures and obtaining highly realistic results even with a small training dataset. Han et al. [229, 230] concentrate on brain magnetic resonance (MR) images. They use progressively growing GANs (PGGAN) [311] to generate 256×256256256256\times 256 MR images and then compare two different refinement approaches: SimGAN [545] as discussed in Section 6.1.1 and UNIT [370], an unsupervised image-to-image translation architecture that maps each domain into a shared latent space with a VAE-GAN architecture [345] (we remark that the original paper [370] also applies UNIT, among other things, to synthetic-to-real translation). Han et al. report improved results when combining GAN-based synthetic data with classic domain adaptation techniques. Neff [422] uses a slightly different approach: to generate synthetic data for segmentation, he uses a standard WGAN-GP architecture [217] but generates image-segmentation pairs, i.e., images with an additional channel that shows the segmentation mask.
